\begin{abstract}
{Fundamental forces of Nature are described by field theories,
also known as gauge theories, based on a local gauge invariance.
The simplest of them is quantum electrodynamics (QED), which is an
example of an Abelian gauge theory. Such theories describe the
dynamics of massless photons and their coupling to matter.
However, in two spatial dimension (2D) they are known to exhibit gapped phases at low
temperature. In the realm of quantum spin systems, it remains a
subject of considerable debate if their low energy physics can be
described by emergent gauge degrees of freedom. Here we present a
class of simple two-dimensional models that admit a low energy description in terms of an
Abelian gauge theory. We find rich phase diagrams for
these models comprising exotic deconfined phases and gapless phases  -
a rare example for 2D Abelian gauge theories. The counter-intuitive presence of gapless
phases in 2D  results from the emergence of additional symmetry in
the models. Moreover, we propose schemes to realize our model with 
current experiments using ultracold bosonic atoms in optical
lattices}
\end{abstract}

\pacs{67.85.Lm, 03.75.Lm, 73.43.-f}
\maketitle
\section{Introduction}
Gauge theories based on the principle of local gauge invariance
provide foundations of our current understanding of fundamental
forces of nature. The simplest of them, quantum electrodynamics,
describes the dynamics of gauge bosons (photons) and their
coupling to matter (electrons). One of the central ideas in modern
physics concerns thus the concept of a local gauge invariance.
With the advent of  quantum spin liquids \cite{and}, it has been
proposed that gauge bosons can be emergent. Quantum spin liquids
represent states of matter that do not break any global symmetry.
It was suggested that the low energy spectrum of spin liquids, or
more generally certain low-dimensional quantum spin systems (and
related strongly correlated fermionic systems) can be described by
emergent gauge bosons \cite{fradkin1, wen1, lee}. These gauge
bosons emerge naturally in a mean field description of the models.
Unfortunately, it has also been found that most of the times
fluctuations destroy such a nice description by strongly binding
the gauge bosons \cite{kog1, horn, drell, banks} and producing a low
energy sector dominated by standard spin fluctuations. For this
reason the validity of such an emergent gauge theory  descriptions
still remains a subject of a considerable debate \cite{lee, param,
fish, muramatsu, sorella, mot}.

In particular, in spacial 2D (2+1 dimensions, if time is
considered), low energy sector of Abelian gauge theories with
$U(1)$ gauge symmetry exhibits gapped confined phase, as pointed
out first by Polyakov \cite{Polyakov1,Polyakov2}. For discrete
gauge symmetry ($\mathbb{Z}_N$) both confined and deconfined phases exist \cite{horn,drell}; both are gapped, however, and
the extent of the latter in the parameter space vanishes as $N$ tends to infinity.


 Rather
than asking if the low energy description of a given model
Hamiltonian can be expressed in terms of a gauge theory, one could
take the complementary approach of characterizing all possible
phases described by gauge theories to see if some of them resemble
those that we observe in strongly correlated spin/fermionic
systems. Unfortunately, typically these systems are notoriously
difficult to characterize analytically and numerically. That has
led many authors to propose novel quantum simulators schemes that
would allow to characterize the phases of gauge Hamiltonians
\cite{kog1} with ultra-cold atoms\cite{buch, edina, reznik, cirac0, luca,
zoller1, cirac1, lew1, reznik2, wiesse, zohar}.

In the present paper we follow a complementary approach, we consider the low energy physics of a class of bosonic Hamiltonians
and show how they can be described
by a set of emerging gauge theories, we also propose and design experimentally
feasible ways to quantum simulate them. Our Hamiltonian 
 describe two-species bosons hopping on a two dimensional
square lattice. Depending on the tunneling geometry of one of the
bosonic species (referred to as auxiliary particles), one obtains
different low energy emerging gauge theories for the other
particles.

Our main results are that the low-energy sector of the remaining bosons can always be
characterized by an emergent gauge theory. More specifically it
can be described in terms of collective plaquette degrees of
freedom \cite{horn, drell} of the original bosons. These
collective plaquette variables can be thought as arising from
gauge bosons living on a coarse-grained version of the original
lattice. The emerging gauge theories are Abelian, but can have a discrete
$\mathbb{Z}_N$ or continuous $U(1)$ invariance. They are exotic, in the sense that they differ from the standard
Hamiltonian models \cite{banks,horn,drell} that only exhibit gapped
(confined or not) phases. For our models, however, we
encounter an additional set of symmetries, conserving charges along
columns of the lattice. As a consequence of such symmetries, and of the related breaking of rotation invariance, we find
that the ground state contains exotic gapped deconfined phases
with dipolar and kink excitations to gapless Bose-liquids. Importantly, our  models can be realized with currently existing
experimental techniques with ultracold atoms, as we discuss in the
Methods section.


\section{The model}
We define a 2D lattice system with sites identified by Latin
letters $i \equiv (x,y)$. The links are denoted by the
pair$(i,\delta)$, where $i$ denote the site they originate from and $\delta$ the direction they point to, it is understood that  the direction can be
$\delta= \hat{x}, \hat{y}$. With a
light abuse of notation we also identify the nearest neighbor of
site $i$ in the direction $\delta$ as site $i+\delta$. On each
site of the lattice we have two species of bosons:
\emph{auxiliary} {\it  a}-bosons and {\it b}-bosons. The creation
and annihilation operators for the two species are respectively
$\hat{a}^{\dagger}_i$, $\hat{a}_i$ and $\hat{b}^{\dagger}_{i}$,
$\hat{b}_{i}$. The number operator for {\it b}-bosons is defined
as $\hat{n}_{i}=\hat{b}^{\dagger}_{i}\hat{b}_{i}$. We assume that
{\it a}-bosons are hardcore, and thus we can have at most one {\it
a}-boson per site. We also  define the difference of the number
operators of {\it b}-bosons  on neighboring sites, that naturally
lives on the link $(i,\delta)$ that connects the two sites,
$\hat{n}_{(i, \delta)}\equiv (\hat{n}_{{i+\delta}}-\hat{n}_{i})$.


We focus on the low energy physics of the Hamiltonian
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{hameff}
H &=& -\sum_{i,\delta} \left( J_a(i, \delta) \hat{a}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \exp\left[i\alpha_{{\delta}}\hat{n}_{(i,\delta)} \right]\hat{a}_{i+\delta} + h.c. \right )\nonumber
 \\
 &-&J_b\sum_{i,\delta} \left(\hat{b}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{b}_{{i}+{\delta}} + h.c. \right )
,
\end{eqnarray}
where {\it h.c.} stands for Hermitian conjugate. This is a generalization of the Bose-Hubbard Hamiltonian, 
in which the tunneling amplitudes of {\it  a}-bosons are link dependent, $J_a(i,\delta)$,  while those for {\it b}-bosons $J_b$ are uniform. More importantly phases of the tunneling amplitudes of {\it  a}-bosons are modulated by the occupation of  {\it b}-bosons on neighboring sites as illustrated in the right-hand panel of Fig.\ref{figure1}a.  The strength of the modulation, $\alpha_{{\delta}}$, depends on the direction. It vanishes along the $x$ direction $\alpha_{x}=0$, while $\alpha_{y}=\alpha=[2\pi/N]$
 ($N$ is an positive integer and [.] denotes here  the box function). Similar models have been considered recently in  \cite{keilmann11,edmonds13,greschner14,arek, dutta15,greschner15,santos1,anna15,biedron16,bermudez15,david1}. The lattice configurations for both bosons are shown in Fig.\ref{figure1}a. 
The {\it b}-bosons are assumed to be non-interacting. 

\begin{figure*}

\caption{Pictorial summary - (a) \textbf{Left panel:} The super-lattice geometry for the auxiliary particles. The considered tunneling amplitudes are  $J_a(\mathbf{i}\bm{\delta}_x)=J_a >0 $ if $i_x$ is odd and $J_a(\mathbf{i}\bm{\delta}_x)=J'_a >0,J'_a < J_a$ otherwise. Each dimerized link is filled with hardcore auxiliary {\it a}-boson. \textbf{Middle panel:} One-dimensional tubes of {\it b}-bosons arranged in a square lattice geometry. The sites of the lattices for {\it b}-bosons and {\it a}-bosons in $xy$-plane overlap. \textbf{Right panel:} The tunneling of the {\it a}-bosons along the $y$-direction is modified in phase by the presence  of {\it b}-bosons on the link. (b) \textbf{Left panel:} We consider a dimer state for the half-filled {\it a}-bosons. Such a state is an exact ground state for vanishing inter-link tunneling, i.e. $J'_a=0$. From that, we construct the coarse-grained dual lattice (shown by the wiggly blue lines) where the electric fields and the vector potentials live. In the background, the dark grey-white region shows the original lattice structure.}

In the present article we show that the low energy sector of Hamiltonian \eqref{hameff}, is described by an exotic gauge theory for {\it b}-bosons filling $\bar{n} \gg 1 $. Furthermore, the above Hamiltonian can be engineered experimentally in an ultra-cold atoms set up. In that context the {\it a}-bosons tunneling inhomogeneity can be realized by trapping them in optical super-lattices. The large filling of {\it b}-bosons is obtained by allowing  the {\it b}-bosons to form extended tubes \cite{seng0} along a direction perpendicular to the lattice. Such species dependent traps have been demonstrated experimentally by using state-selective optical lattices \cite{bloch, hem, ess, seng1,seng2,seng}. The last ingredient is the possibility to tune both interaction among {\it a}-bosons and {\it b}-bosons, at the same time ensuring that {\it b}-bosons do not interact. This requires an accurate choice of the species representing the bosons. For example one could choose  $^{39}$K-$^{133}$Cs mixture that has the 
necessary hyperfine structure accompanied by a rich landscape of Feshbach resonances \cite{patel}.
We provide in the Appendix, two different schemes using periodic shaking mechanisms of the optical lattice that allow to generate the Hamiltonian, Eq.~\eqref{hameff}, after time-averaging.

\section{Low energy excitations}

We consider {\it a}-bosons hopping on a dimerized lattice as presented in the left-hand panel of Fig.~\ref{figure1}b. The {\it a}-bosons are in the insulating phase when the tunnelings between the dimer links vanish. The insulating phase is represented by each dimerized link containing exactly one {\it a}-bosons as in Fig.~\ref{figure1}b. For weak inter-dimer tunnelings, different dimer links are mixed and we obtain an effective potential for {\it b}-bosons due to phase modulation of the inter-dimer tunnelings. At second order of the perturbation theory the effective potential for the {\it b}-bosons depends on a linear combination of occupations around the shaded plaquettes $p$ containing the sites $i,i+\hat{x},i+\hat{x}+\hat{y},i+\hat{y}$ for odd $i_x$. The low-energy effective potential reads, $H_{\rm pot}=-2K\sum_p \cos {\left[\hat{\mathcal{B}}_{p}\right]}$ where the plaquette operator $\hat{\mathcal{B}}$ is introduced as $\hat{\mathcal{B}}_{p} \equiv\frac{2\pi}{N}\left(\hat{n}_i - \hat{n}_{i+\hat{x}} + \hat{n}_{
i+\hat{x}+ \hat{y}} - \hat{n}_{i+\hat{y}}\right)$ and plaquette strength $K = 2J'^2_{ a}/J_a $. The $\hat{\mathcal{B}}$ operator has eigenvalues $\mathcal{B} \in (2\pi/N)\left[-(N-1)/2,..-1,0,1,....(N-1)/2\right]$. Following the standard procedure \cite{drell}, we introduce the ladder operator, $\mathcal{L}$,  to construct a $\mathcal{Z}_N$ algebra.  $\mathcal{L}$ fulfills the following commutation  relations with the operator $\hat{\mathcal{B}}$ defined on the same plaquette $p$,

\subsection{Gauge theory on the coarse-grained lattice}

The $\mathcal{Z}_N$ Hamiltonian \eqref{plaqham1} describes a spin model defined on the dual lattice whose sites are at the centers of plaquettes of the original lattice.  Therefore, by performing a duality transformation, we can go back to the original lattice and write the spin model as a gauge theory.
Since originally \eqref{plaqham1} involves only every second plaquette, the lattice, where the gauge theory is defined, is a coarse-grained version of the original lattice made by grouping  together $2$ plaquettes inside the $2\times 1$ squares as shown in Fig.~\ref{figure1}(b).
As a result, from now on, the plaquette index $p$ denotes the entire $2$ plaquettes group. We reverse the standard duality between gauge and spin systems \cite{fradkin2, horn, drell, fradkin1, savit,luca2} and define the electric-field operator  $\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i,\hat{x})}=\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p}-\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p -\hat{y}}$ on the links of the coarse grained lattice.
Similarly $\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i,\hat{y})}=-\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{{p}}+\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p-\hat{x}}$. By construction, the electric-field operators obey Gauss law: $\sum_{\delta} \hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i,\delta)}- \hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i-\delta, \delta)}=0$.
The relation between $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$  and $\hat{\mathcal{L}}$ can be inverted in several ways, one possibility is $\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p}= \sum^{n=0}_{n=-\infty}\hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i-n \hat{x},\hat{y})}$.
Under the same duality transformation, the plaquette magnetic field is transformed to the standard curl of the Wilson line, $e^{i\hat{\mathcal{B}}_{p}} \equiv \hat{U}_{(i,\hat{x})} \hat{U}_{(i+\hat{x},\hat{y})}\hat{U}^{\dagger}_{(i+\hat{y},\hat{x})} \hat{U}^{\dagger}_{(i,\hat{y})}$ 
where the $\hat{U}$ operator has the same form as the  $\exp [i \hat{\mathcal{B}}]$ operator, but is defined on the links of the lattice. Since also $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$ has the same form as $\hat{\mathcal{L}}$,  $\hat{U}$ and $\hat{\mathcal{E}}$ fulfill the commutation relations \eqref{eq:zn} for the same link and commute for different links. After the duality transformation, the Hamiltonian \eqref{plaqham1} becomes,

an excitation energy $\Delta E_{\uparrow}=2(1-\cos 2\pi/N) - 6g^2$. Similarly, one could construct magnetic dipoles oriented along $-y$-direction  with the opposite sign in the exponent. As opposed to magnetic charges, the dipoles delocalize by tunneling along both lattice directions due to the last two terms in the Hamiltonian \eqref{eq:gaugeham} as pictorially sketched in Fig.~\ref{figure2}(b). 

For $N>3$, the zero momentum magnetic dipole state has lower energy than the magnetic charge state for all coupling strength. Thus for $N\le3$ and for a very weak coupling the lower excitations are magnetic charge states and the ground state is similar to the one of  the deconfined phase of the corresponding standard gauge theories. We can construct a column Fourier basis  $\ket{\mathcal{B}}_{p_x} = 1/\sqrt{3}\sum_{\mathcal{L}} \exp (i \mathcal{B} \mathcal{L}) \ket{\mathcal{L}}_{p_x}$.
In particular we can see that the ladder operator for the $\ket{\mathcal{L}}_{p_x}$ is given by $  \exp (i \hat{\mathcal{B}})_{p_x} =\prod_{p_y}  \exp (i \hat{\mathcal{B}}_{(p_x, p_y)})$.
If we now consider a large but finite $g$, the ground state degeneracy splits for finite systems.
The ladder operator for   $\ket{\mathcal{L}}_{p_x}$ can be only obtained at order $1/g^L$ of the perturbation theory. So we expect that the ground state is
$\ket{\Omega} = \prod_{p_x}\ket{\mathcal{B}=0}_{p_x}$ and all  other $N^L-1$ states should still be exponentially close.
The first excited state (see Fig.~\ref{figure2}(d)) is again made of a manifold of states where one of the column state is changed from $\ket{\mathcal{L}}_{p_x}$ to $1/{\sqrt{L}}\sum_y \ket{\mathcal{L}^1 \mathcal{L}^2}_{p_x,y}$, where $\ket{\mathcal{L}^1 \mathcal{L}^2}_{p_x,y} = \prod_{p_y< y } \ket{\mathcal{L}^1}_{(p_x,p_y)} \otimes \prod_{p_y\ge y } \ket{\mathcal{L}^2}_{(p_x,p_y)}$ and $\mathcal{L}^1, \mathcal{L}^2$ are two different eigenvalues of the $\hat{\mathcal{L}}$ operator.
These states have a gap of order $1$ over the ground state manifold. Interestingly these excitations are localized in the $x$ direction, since once more their hopping only arises at order $L$ of the perturbation theory.
Nevertheless there is no energy cost related to separating two of them in the $x$ direction so that they are energetically deconfined. The same holds in the y direction, so that these domain walls are deconfined in both direction.

Next we check the periodic QED limit \cite{drell,horn} defined by  $N \rightarrow \infty $ and $g \rightarrow \infty$ with  $2\pi g/N =$ constant.  The spectrum of the magnetic field operator, $\hat{\mathcal{B}}$ becomes continuous spectrum $\in [0,2\pi)$. Using the Villain approximation and carrying out the standard manipulations \cite{fradkin1}, the partition function corresponding to the Hamiltonian in \eqref{eq:gaugeham} in Euclidean space-time is expressed as,

\forall\ket{\mathcal{L}}_{p_{x}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">{</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></munder><msub><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">}</mo></mrow><mo mathvariant="italic" separator="true"> </mo><mrow><mo>∀</mo><msub><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi></msub></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where the scaled distance is defined as $\bar{r}=(\tau,[4 \pi g/N]y )$, $q(\bar{r},x)$ denotes a vortex or charge with strength $q$ at position $(\bar{r},x)$.

The divergence of $G(0)$ ensures the charge neutrality condition. Moreover, due to the symmetry of the original Hamiltonian, the partition function becomes equivalent to that of a two dimensional classical Coulomb gas, instead of a three dimensional Coulomb gas in standard pQED.
This results in a drastic change of the  phases  of the gauge Hamiltonian as two dimensional Coulomb gas allows for gapless free photons. When $ g/N< 1/4$ (effective low temperature phase of the Coulomb gas), the charges interact via exchange of photons creating effective un-screened long-range Coulomb force. The fluctuations are then highly anisotropic gapless photons with dispersion in the long-wavelength limit $(2\pi/N)\sqrt{\bar{n}J_bK} k_y$, where $k_y$ is $y$ component of the momentum. For $ g/N > 1/4$ the charges becomes free and the photons acquire a finite mass. We present in Fig.~\ref{figure2}(e) a summary of the qualitative phase diagram.


In conclusion, we have proposed an ultracold gas model with periodic modulations of lattice and interaction parameters capable of simulating dynamical gauge fields. We have investigated the low-energy excitations of the resulting time-averaged dressed model and showed that the collective excitations are analogs of free electromagnetic fields  with gapless photons. We have sketched an experimental procedure to measure the resulting correlations of non-local operations. We believe that our present study will open a new route towards study of gauge fields in bosonic and fermionic matter, extensions to non-Abelian groups, possible phases at higher or lower dimensions. It would be very interesting to confirm via numerical Monte Carlo simulations or recently developed tensor network simulations \cite{luca2,luca3, frank,mc,zoller} the details of the  phase diagram sketched in Fig.~\ref{figure2}  of the Hamiltonian \eqref{eq:gaugeham}.

\section{Methods}

\subsection{Plaquette representation of {\it b}-boson tunneling}
We show an example of  a projection of the kinetic energy operator for $b$-bosons in Eq.\eqref{hameff}, $J_b\sum_{i,\delta} \left(\hat{b}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{b}_{{i}+{\delta}} + h.c. \right )$, on the plaquette basis states $\left |\mathcal{B}_p \right \rangle$. We give a generic example of such a operation for the scheme:
\begin{eqnarray} \label{tunn}
&& \hat{b}^{\dagger}_i \hat{b}_{i+\hat{x}}\left |\mathcal{B}_p,\mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}} \right \rangle;\quad {i}_x \in odd  \nonumber\\
&=& \sqrt{(n_{b,i}+1){n}_{b,i+\hat{x}}} \left |\mathcal{B}_p + \frac{4\pi}{N}, \mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}} - \frac{4\pi}{N} \right \rangle \nonumber\\
&\approx & \bar{n} e^{- i \frac{4\pi}{N} \left[ \hat{\mathcal{L}}_p - \hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p-\hat{y}} \right]} \left | \mathcal{B}_p, \mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}} \right\rangle, \nonumber\\
&& \hat{b}^{\dagger}_i \hat{b}_{i+\hat{y}}\left |\mathcal{B}_p,\mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}},\mathcal{B}_{p+\hat{y}}  \right \rangle  \nonumber\\
&=& \sqrt{(n_{b,i}+1){n}_{b,i+\hat{y}}} \left |\mathcal{B}_p - \frac{4\pi}{N}, \mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}} + \frac{2\pi}{N}, \mathcal{B}_{p+\hat{y}} + \frac{2\pi}{N} \right \rangle \nonumber\\
&\approx & \bar{n} e^{i \frac{2\pi}{N} \left[ \hat{2\mathcal{L}}_p - 2\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p-\hat{y}} 2\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{p+\hat{y}} \right]} \left | \mathcal{B}_p, \mathcal{B}_{p-\hat{y}},\mathcal{B}_{p+\hat{y}} \right\rangle,
\end{eqnarray}
where the final expression is valid only for a large bosonic filling, $\bar{n} \gg 1$. In \eqref{tunn}, the first (second) term leads  to second (third) tunneling expression in Eq.\eqref{plaqham1}.

\subsection{Partition function of the $Z_N$ gauge system-weak coupling limit}

In the weak coupling limit, first we carry out the following transformation: $\hat{\mathcal{B}}_p\rightarrow \frac{2\pi}{N} \hat{{\mathcal{B}}}_p$ and $\frac{2\pi}{N} \hat{\mathcal{E}}_{(i,\delta)} \rightarrow \hat{{\mathcal{E}}}_{(i,\delta)}$. The transformed $\hat{\mathcal{B}}_{\bm{p}}$ has an integer spectrum. In the weak-coupling limit of $N \rightarrow \infty $ and $g \rightarrow 0$ with fixed $\tilde{g}= Ng/2\pi$, the Hamiltonian \eqref{plaqham1} takes a form,
\begin{eqnarray}\label{weak}
\frac{N^2}{4\pi^2 K }H_{\rm gauge}&=&\sum_{i} \hat{\mathcal{B}}^2_p - 2 \tilde{g}^2 \left[ 2\sum_i  \cos\left (\mathcal{E}_{(i,\hat{x})}-\mathcal{E}_{(i+\hat{y},\hat{x})}\right) \right. \nonumber\\
&+& \left. \cos\left(\mathcal{E}_{(i,\hat{x})}-\mathcal{E}_{(i+\hat{x},\hat{x})}\right)+\cos2\mathcal{E}_{(i,\hat{x})} \right] ,
\end{eqnarray}
where $i$ is the site connected to the plaquette $p=(i,i+\hat{x},i+\hat{x}+\hat{y},i+\hat{y})$. We define the state with a single dipole of strength $\mathcal{M}$ on the link $(i,\hat{x})$ of coarse-grained lattice as,

where $\omega$ is the shaking frequency and $V_{\rm sh}$ is e.g. the amplitude modulation strength. The modulation of lattice depth not only induces the time dependence in tunneling but also induces periodic modulation in single-particle onsite energies. However, since the tunneling rates depend exponentially on the lattice depth the main effect of the lattice modulation is on tunneling rates. The shaking frequency, while large, should not be resonant with the energy difference between the $s$ and $p$ bands  \cite{lacki13}.

Observe that not only the tunnelings but also interactions between species are assumed to be modulated. The latter
can be performed with the help of magnetic Feshbach resonance (see below for discussion of possible choice of atomic species).

The Hamiltonian thus becomes $H(t)=H_0+H_{\rm sh}$. To perform time-averaging over fast oscillations we
 apply the unitary transformation:  $\hat{U}=\exp [- { i} U_{\rm sh}  \sum_{{j}} \hat{n}_{a{j}} \hat{n}_{b{j}} \int^t_0 \sin\omega t' dt']$ which transfers the time-dependence of the total Hamiltonian $H(t)$ into the tunneling amplitudes yielding $H_1=\hat{U}^\dagger H \hat{U} - {i}\hat{U}^\dagger [d_t \hat{U}]$. Using  Jacobi-Anger Identity the Hamiltonian may be expressed as
\begin{eqnarray}
H_1 &=& H_{\rm a,av} + H_{\rm b,av}  + H_{\rm t} + H^{\dag}_{\rm t}, \nonumber\\
H_{\rm a,av} &=& -\sum_{{i},{\delta}} \hat{a}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \mathcal{F}_{{i\delta}} \hat{U}_{{i\delta}} \hat{a}_{{i}+{\delta}} - h.c.
\nonumber\\
H_{\rm b,av} &=& -J_{\rm b,av}\sum_{{i},{\delta}} \hat{b}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{b}_{{i}+{\delta}} - h.c.\nonumber\\
H_{t}&=&- \sum_{{i},{\delta},} J_{\rm a}({i\delta})\sum_{M\neq 0} i^M \mathcal{J}_M(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i{\delta}}}/\omega)e^{iM\omega t}\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{a}_{{i}+{\delta}}  \nonumber\\
&+& \cos \omega t\sum_{{i},{\delta}}\sum_{M \neq \pm 1} T_{{\delta}} i^M\mathcal{J}_M(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i}{\delta}}/\omega)e^{iM\omega t}\hat{a}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{a}_{{i}+{\delta}}
\nonumber\\
&-&J_{\rm b}\sum_{{i},{\delta}}\sum_{M\neq 0} i^M \mathcal{J}_M(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{a{i{\delta}}}/\omega)e^{iM\omega t}\hat{b}^{\dagger}_{{i}} \hat{b}_{{i}+{\delta}},
\end{eqnarray}
with the tunneling amplitudes taking quite complicated form
\begin{eqnarray} \label{timeavg}
\mathcal{F}_{{i\delta}} &=& \sqrt{J^2_a({i\delta})\mathcal{J}^2_0(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}/\omega)+T^2_{{\delta}}\mathcal{J}^2_1(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}/\omega)} \nonumber\\
\hat{U}_{{i\delta}} &=& \exp\left[-i\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{T_{{\delta}}\mathcal{J}_1(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}/\omega)}{J_a({i\delta})\mathcal{J}_0(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}/\omega)}\right)\right], \\
{J}_{\rm b, av}&=&J_b\mathcal{J}_0(U_{\rm sh}\hat{n}_{a{i\delta}}/\omega).\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
with, let us recall, $\hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}=\hat{n}_{b{i+\delta}} -\hat{n}_{b{i}}$ being the difference of population operators for tubes separated by ${\delta}$. While for each tube $\bar{n}>>1$, $\langle \hat{n}_{b{i\delta}} \rangle \ll \bar{n}$.
The tunneling of auxiliary particles is thus modulated dynamically both in amplitude \cite{dutta, santos1} and in phase by the presence of the $b$-bosons.

The expressions \eqref{timeavg} simplify considerably assuming that the shaken tunneling component value
is chosen such that $T_{{\delta}}\approx \sqrt{2} J_a$. Then for
$U_{\rm sh} \bar{n}/\omega \lesssim 1$ one obtains the following approximate expressions
$\mathcal{F}_{{i\delta}} \approx J_a({i\delta})$,  $\hat{U}_{{i\delta}} \approx \exp\left[-i\alpha_{{\delta}} \hat{n}_{b{i\delta}}\right]$ and ${J}_{\rm b, av} \approx J_b$. Since the tunneling shaking is assumed along $y$ direction only we have
 $\alpha_{{\delta}_x}=0$, $\alpha_{{\delta}_y}=  U_{\rm sh}/\sqrt{2}\omega$.
 This approximation even for $U_{\rm sh} \bar{n}/\omega=1$ yields the error  less than ten percent. Within this approximation the $b$-boson tunneling remains unchanged.


 One can then apply another unitary operations which will introduce extra terms due to the non-commuting interaction and tunneling operators leading to additional terms  of the order of $J_a^2/\omega^2, T^2_{{\delta}}/\omega^2$. In the present study, we assume a regime where $J_a, T_{\delta} \ll \omega$, so such terms may be safely ignored. Dropping $H_t$ altogether (as it averages to zero over the period of the perturbation) we arrive at \eqref{hameff}.

\noindent{\it Scheme B: Quasi-resonant lattice shaking}

The previous proposal allows to make weak modulation of tunneling phases.
To reach the regime of strong phase modulated tunneling, we introduce another shaking scheme. Here we assume a standard lattice shaking potential \cite{Eckardt05,seng0} represented by the Hamiltonian,
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{shak_b}
H_{\rm sh}(t) &=&  K\cos\omega t \sum_{{i}} (i_x+i_y) \hat{n}_{b{i}}  \nonumber\\
&+& K \sum_{{i}} \left[i_x\cos\omega t +
i_y\cos(\omega t + \phi) \right ]\hat{n}_{a{i}} ,
\end{eqnarray}
where observe the additional phase difference in shaking for {\it a}-species. This is easily accomplished since we assume different lattices for both species anyway. As before we assume $\omega$ to be much larger than $J_a$ but
additionally we assume this frequency to be resonantly adjusted to the interspecies interaction strength $U_{ab}$
(or the latter to be modified by Feshbach resonance) with the condition $U_{ab}\approx  \mathcal{N}\omega$ with
$\mathcal{N}$ being an integer.

To average over the fast oscillations one has now to take this resonant condition into account. Define

V_{\rm a}(t)= V_{\rm sh} \cos\omega t \sin^2(2\pi y/\lambda),

\label{shak_b}

&+& K \sum_{{i}} \left[i_x\cos\omega t +
i_y\cos(\omega t + \phi) \right ]\hat{n}_{a{i}} ,
\end{eqnarray}

additionally we assume this frequency to be resonantly adjusted to the interspecies interaction strength $U_{ab}$
(or the latter to be modified by Feshbach resonance) with the condition $U_{ab}\approx  \mathcal{N}\omega$ with

Again, in the limit of fast $\omega$ compared to other tunneling scales, we carry out the time-averaging procedure, as for the first scheme, resulting in the effective Hamiltonian:

\begin{eqnarray}
H_1 &=& H_{\rm a} + H_{\rm b}+(U_{ab}-\mathcal{N}\omega ) \sum_{{i}} \hat{n}_{a{i}}\hat{n}_{b{i}}, \nonumber\\

\nonumber\\

\end{eqnarray}
where $\alpha_{{\delta_x}}=0, \alpha_{{\delta_y}}=\alpha=\mathcal{N} \phi$ and  $\beta_{{\delta_x}}=0,\  \beta_{{\delta_y}}=K\sin\phi/\omega$. The averaging procedure is valid provid
$\omega$ is much larger than the tunnelings and $U_{ab}-\mathcal{N}\omega\ll \omega$.
